entry.title: Balmenach 2004 Hidden Spirits 13 years 51.2% (exbourbon)
entry.content:
An honest little exbourbon malt from Hidden Spirits, one of my favourite bottlers. From a rather obscure distillery.

Colour Straw, amber.

Nose Tropical fruits! Pawpaw, rockmelon, mango. Very clear. Cinnamon sticks from afar. Fennel and light sweetness. Passionfruit sorbet. Lemon sherbet. Lemon zest. Fresh woodiness, almost wet, like trees after rain. More passionfruit. After water, strawberry jam on pancakes. Butter.

Palate Creamy. Rice pudding. Those lemons are back, bringing with them toffee and custard bombolone. Sauternes?! Crème patisserie. Sweet pastries and croissants. Minty. After water, some more woodiness and vanilla custard sweetness. Ripe nectarines and peaches. Light minerality and acidity.

Finish Menthol, eucalyptus, and lovely sweet pound cake. Powerfully warming. Toffee. Very long. Mango sorbet and vanilla. A big whack of vanilla, like those bombolone. Whipped cream and vanilla beans. Whiffs of oak rounding out the whole thing. After water, even creamier. Like a sundae! Or a banoffee tart. The creamy banana goes on forever: long.

Comments Masterclass exbourbon. Passionfruit nose is amazing, and the clarity of the bombolone pastry/vanilla/cream notes is spectacular. Big fan of Hidden Spirits. 90/100.
entry.summary: An honest little exbourbon malt from Hidden Spirits, one of my favourite bottlers. From a rather obscure distillery.

entry.title: Teaninich 2006 Hidden Spirits 13 years 51.7% (exbourbon)
entry.content:
Another Hidden Spirit, this time from Teaninich. Not quite as obscure as Balmenach, but not exactly hyped… hope you like salad.

Colour Straw.

Nose Huge malt. big banana. Candlewax? Watermelon, rockmelon. Stone fruits. A bit of a fruit platter here. Cucumber and a bit of salt. A little meaty after some time. Very full. With a bit of water, reveals floral notes.

Palate Woah. Light Cucumber and caramel. Watermelon and salt. Fresh melons and lemonade icy-poles. Caramel and toffee, brown sugar. Malt, corn flakes. Cucumber again! What’s going on? With water, sweeter, sugar cookies.

Finish Perfumed. Dried fruits. Chai lattes and apples. Fresh salad (cucumber…). Very long, very pleasant.

Comments Haha, so weird. Cucumber and salad? Melons and meat? Typical fresh fruits and caramel? Wild stuff. 88/100.
entry.summary: Another Hidden Spirit, this time from Teaninich. Not quite as obscure as Balmenach, but not exactly hyped… hope you like salad.

entry.title: Springbank “Cask Strength” 12 years 55.3% (2020)
entry.content:
The 2020 release of Springbank’s cask strength 12 year old. From what I gather, it’s 35 per cent sherry and 65 per cent exbourbon.

Colour Deep gold.

Nose Rubber and soot, yeasty funk. Springbank funk. Apricots. Figs and dates. Berry jams. Vanilla bean sugar. Filo pastry. Cream and tropical fruits: bananas, mangoes. Fennel and mint. Blueberry yoghurt. Wood and earth. With water, woodier and earthier, and a hint of chocolate, and a little roasty.

Palate Thick. Very sweet! Golden syrup over pancakes, lemon and sugar. Citrus peels. Oily. Very dirty, earthy – light peat. Leathery. A little smoke. Rice pudding, fresh orchard fruits, fruit jams, and creamy malt. Rubber and wood. Dirt.

Finish Hot – intense. Raspberry jam and rubbery funk. Soot and ash. Coffee and milk. Cream. Pears. A little tannic. Long.

Comments Monstrous. A striking balance between rubbery funk, earthy peat, and fruity notes. 90/100.
entry.summary: The 2020 release of Springbank’s cask strength 12 year old. From what I gather, it’s 35 per cent sherry and 65 per cent exbourbon.

entry.title: Glenrothes 2006 Wilson and Morgan 48% (first fill sherry butts)

link.title: Glenrothes 2006 Wilson and Morgan 48% (first fill sherry butts)

entry.content:
A vatting of three casks. First fill sherry butts.

Colour Rose gold.

Nose Sherry! Dried fruits and brown sugar. A little cheesy? Definitely. Cheddar and black pepper. Oak and baking spices. Armagnac.

Palate Full and creamy. Dried fruits, apricot delight. Peaches and nectarines. Brightness: orange juice. Jaffa cakes. Sweet malt. Oak tannins. Thick caramel and brown sugar: very Glenrothes. Lollipops and vanilla. Tannic. Hazelnuts and walnuts.

Finish Warming and spicy. Fruit mince tarts and tiramisu. Rummy: molasses. Oak. Long. A little tannic and stemmy. Stewed pears. Nutty.

Comments Straightforward, honest, sherry forward dram. Loving the Glenrothes malt — caramel works so well. 83/100.
entry.summary: A vatting of three casks. First fill sherry butts.

entry.title: Blair Athol 2003 Douglas of Drumlanrig 12 years 46% (refill hogshead)

link.title: Blair Athol 2003 Douglas of Drumlanrig 12 years 46% (refill hogshead)

entry.content:
Presumably an exbourbon refill hoggy. One of Diageo’s blend focused distilleries.

Colour Light straw.

Nose Fresh fruits and bananas, perfume and menthol. Boiled sweets and sweetened cream. Heady, alcoholic, surprising for a 46 per cent.

Palate Caramel. A slight astringency. Malt, bright acidic oranges. Oily zest. Pretty light, a little grassy and slightly floral.

Finish Nutty, coconut. A little oak and some bitter herbs. Moderate.

Comments Pretty light on. Overall, too simple and dull. Perfumed nose and the zesty notes carry most of the interest. 75/100.
entry.summary: Presumably an exbourbon refill hoggy. One of Diageo’s blend focused distilleries.

entry.title: Ben Nevis 2015 Adelphi 5 years 61.3% (first fill sherry)

link.title: Ben Nevis 2015 Adelphi 5 years 61.3% (first fill sherry)

entry.content:
Adelphi! I got the email for this outturn at ten in the morning, I believe. Three minutes later, this was sold out (alongside most of the other bottles in this outturn). Oh well, c’est la vie. The people love the colour. Judging by the number of bottles (622), probably a sherry butt.

Colour Deep ruby. I guess we know what to expect.

Nose Sherry. Dirty and oily, mint and menthol. Dried fruits and walnuts. Fresh oak. Herbaceous. Heady and alcoholic, but not unpleasant. Perfume. Toffee apples. Pears. Cough syrup. Minty. Lilly pilly.

Palate Oily Bennie smack. Dried fruits, figs and raisins. A little ashy, before moving into dried apricots and more figs. Coco pops, raisin bran, and honey granola. Candied macadamias. Boiled sweets and vanilla. Cola.

Finish Mulled wine. Cinnamon and chilli. Raisins, sultanas, PX. Thick and heavy. Molasses, very long.

Comments Real classic Adelphi sherry bomb. Young Bennie is great stuff. 87/100.

entry.title: Secret Highland 2010 Claxton’s Exploration 10 years 50% (tawny port butt)

link.title: Secret Highland 2010 Claxton’s Exploration 10 years 50% (tawny port butt)

entry.content:
Another Claxton’s Exploration bottling. This time a secret highland. Coordinates are 58.02N, 3.87W.

Colour Rose gold.

Nose Waxy malt – candlewax. Brown sugar and caramelised apples. Apple pie! Cinnamon and a hint of cloves. Vanilla. Dried fruits and red wine – port-like. Fresh apple juice. Very enticing.

Palate Sharp, bright, a little acidity. Sweet and thick too, almost like a nice balsamic vinegar. Huge waxy malt! Stewed and dried fruits, fruit mince tart. Very spicy. Some oak and woodiness. Mulled wine and cinnamon sticks.

Finish Vanilla bean ice cream and cinnamon. Apples. So, apple pie and ice cream. Hot molasses. Malty. Nutella. Moderately long, but the heat and spices do linger. Hot apple juice (yes…).

Comments Cracking stuff. Very harmonious: a sense of apple pie served alongside vanilla ice cream persists throughout the whole experience. You’ll be pleased to know that the malt is indeed there and there’s a few other notes to keep us on our toes. Cheerful – I suspect if the distillery was properly named and bumped to cask strength I’d be paying double the price. 85/100.
entry.summary: Another Claxton’s Exploration bottling. This time a secret highland. Coordinates are 58.02N, 3.87W.

entry.title: Islay 2012 Claxton’s Exploration 8 years 50% (refill sherry butt)

link.title: Islay 2012 Claxton’s Exploration 8 years 50% (refill sherry butt)

entry.content:
The final Claxton’s Exploration I’ll be looking at for now. We’ve got another blended malt – presumably teaspooned. Coordinates are 55.63N, 6.15W. This one leads to a quite legendary south coast Islay distillery. Thoughts on the bottling series itself also after the fold.

Colour Straw.

Nose Peat. Intensely herbal and medicinal. Fire and sand. Seaweed and salt. Heavy, sticky, orange almond cake. Minerally and coastal malt, salty. A little woody, but fresh. Plum sauce and wine gummies (hello cask?). Some pepper and menthol.

Palate Thick, oily and medicinal – almost bitter (this is a pleasant thing). Moss, smoke: peat. South coast in character. Scotch fingers and grain – malt. Black tea. Some sweetness, and a fruity, berry note. Like a handful of blueberries and raspberries. Cream. Interesting contrasts here. Back to grassy and herbal.

Finish Oil and smoke. Cough syrup, but the sweetness isn’t artificial. Varnish. Bready. A touch of olive oil. Moderate, but the peat does power on. And isn’t that what we signed up for?

Comments Classic south coast Islay style. Through the peat it does strike me as a lighter malt. I’m very much enjoying the fresh woodsy notes: herbs, grass. It’s a bit like a forest meeting the coast. 85/100.

All in all, Claxton’s Exploration series is probably my favourite entry level IB lineup. I’m impressed by both the quality and value of these bottlings. I strongly recommend checking it out.

entry.title: Ardmore 2009 Claxton’s Exploration 11 years 50% (refill PX hogshead)

link.title: Ardmore 2009 Claxton’s Exploration 11 years 50% (refill PX hogshead)

entry.content:
Continuing on our Claxton’s Exploration. We’ve got an Ardmore – single malt, very much disclosed distillery. There’s no mystery this time, but the coordinates are 57.35N, 2.74W.

Colour Honey.

Nose Cedarwood and lacquer. Herbal bouquet garni: rosemary, mint, coriander. Peppercorns. Milk chocolate and chilli. Floral malt with a stir of caramel. Light woody peat and smoke.

Palate Looking like we’re starting off with some syrupy raisins. Very sweet. Wait. Chocolate bomb! Huge amounts of milk chocolate combined with a whack of woody peat – the perfect amount. Cedar. Moving into all smoke and chocolatey malt. It’s like someone took a hot chocolate and set it on fire. Malty, caramel body, milky texture. A little bit spicy and that herbal note from the nose flows through here.

Finish Impressively long, unexpected. Hot chocolate. smoke. Hazelnut pralines. Sugared. Leather.

Comments Chocolate and woody peat smoke. A milk chocolate hazelnut praline in a bottle. Impressive, but mostly huge amounts of fun. 86/100.

entry.title: Campbeltown Blend 2015 Claxton’s Exploration 5 years 50% (PX hogshead)

link.title: Campbeltown Blend 2015 Claxton’s Exploration 5 years 50% (PX hogshead)

entry.content:
Part of the inaugural outturn of Claxton’s Exploration series comes a blended malt from Campbeltown. As I understand it, this is a teaspooned malt. It spent only five years in a PX hogshead.

A teaspooned malt is one where a teaspoon (quite literally) of malt from another distillery is added to what would otherwise be a single malt. Legally you can no longer sell it as a single malt. This may have tax advantages or is perhaps demanded by the distillery themselves. If you’re curious as to what the vast majority of this malt is, Claxton’s have helpfully provided longitude and latitude coordinates on the label: 55.43 N, 5.60 W. Happy mapping.

Interestingly this bottle came with a coin underneath the cork seal. You can redeem five of these coins for a well priced exclusive bottle from Claxton’s, presumably to reward people who actually drink whisky.

Colour Amber.

Nose Oranges. Chocolate oranges. Milk chocolate digestives, honey on porridge. There’s a sort of earthiness, dirtiness to this. Fennel and menthol. This one’s pretty alcoholic, but does ease up with some time.

Palate Quite a sweet malt. Classic PX dried fruits: figs, dates, raisins. Tangerines and oranges. A little chalky. Thick honey. It seems ever so slightly peated: some smoke along with earthy chocolate. A little oak.

Finish Citrus peel and milk chocolate. A little spicy: cayenne and cinnamon. It’s a bit like a spiced honey tea. With the chocolate biscuits, of course. Long and especially hot.

Comments This dram needs a bit of time to open up. It’s heady and alcoholic, probably on account of its youth. But despite being a little brash, it’s a delightfully sweet and earthy malt with an orange twist. 82/100.
entry.summary: Part of the inaugural outturn of Claxton’s Exploration series comes a blended malt from Campbeltown. As I understand it, this is a teaspooned malt. It spent only five years in a PX hogshead.
